I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) cluster will support the knowledge 
contribution of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to the Aid for Trade (AfT) initiative led by the 
World Trade Organization (WTO), including participation in the biennial AfT Global Review. 
 
2.  The TA cluster is included in the Management-approved annual work program for the 
Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) as a policy research agenda 
for developing member countries (DMCs) for 2018.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  International trade has been instrumental to rapid economic growth and poverty reduction 
in Asia and the Pacific and will continue to play a key role in meeting the Sustainable Development 
Goals. However, many developing countries, particularly the least developed, face challenges in 
fully benefiting from trade liberalization because of obstacles, such as supply-side capacity and 
trade-related infrastructure, that constrain engagement in international trade. Moreover, the 
benefits  of  trade  liberalization  within  countries  are  not  always  shared  equitably  among  all 
segments of the economy, with micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises and women-led firms 
typically at a disadvantage.2 To fully realize potential trade outcomes for inclusive growth, 
developing countries should focus more on trade liberalization and policy adjustments, as well as 
on  the  investments  necessary  to  address  capacity  and  infrastructure  constraints.3 These 
challenges are exacerbated by DMCs’ lack of understanding of AfT-related issues, including how 
best to maximize the benefits of AfT to achieve inclusive trade-driven growth. The TA cluster will 
address this knowledge gap on AfT's key role in helping DMCs address constraints to inclusive 
trade. 
 
4.  The WTO launched the AfT initiative in 2005 to help recipients maximize the benefits of 
trade openness by improving trade and productive capacity, infrastructure, and institutions. Since 
then, AfT has become an increasingly important part of official development assistance (ODA)—
grants  and  concessional  loans—targeted  at  trade-related  programs  and  projects. 4  The 
centerpiece event of the AfT initiative is the AfT Global Review held every 2 years since 2007 at 
the WTO in Geneva. It brings together stakeholders to take stock of progress and challenges and 
to strengthen monitoring and evaluation to advance the AfT agenda in a coordinated and effective 
manner. ADB is an important partner of the AfT Global Review; its main contribution consists of 
a research report, Aid for Trade in Asia and the Pacific, launched at the AfT Global Review, as 
well as organization of side events. The report provides an update on AfT trends and patterns in 
Asia and the Pacific. In addition, the report includes in-depth analyses on topical issues related 
to the inclusiveness and sustainability of trade growth, in the context of a biennial work program 
approved and circulated by WTO’s Committee for Trade and Development. This work program

issues, hence the need to continuously provide updated knowledge solutions. 
 
5.  While global trade growth further accelerated in 2017, of which Asia has been the key 
driver, the global economic environment continues to pose challenges.5 As rising protectionist 
tendencies and challenges to the multilateral global trade architecture threaten nascent recovery 
in trade growth, the capacity of AfT measures to produce positive results has become more vital, 
which includes building a case on the importance of continued trade liberalization. Empirical 
analysis indicates that AfT has played an essential role in the region’s positive trade performance 
in goods and services, and in generation of inclusive job opportunities (footnote 3). 
 
6.  Under ADB’s Strategy 2030, ADB will sustain efforts to eradicate extreme poverty and 
expand its vision to achieve a prosperous, inclusive, resilient, and sustainable Asia and the 
Pacific.6 The Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020 identified 
increased opportunities for cross-border trade and investment among key elements for raising 
competitiveness in connected markets, which in turn is essential for generating inclusive and 
sustainable growth.7 ADB will also further strengthen its role as a knowledge provider. Strategy 
2030  underscores  the  value  of  ADB’s  knowledge  and  evidence-based  research  in  raising 
understanding and awareness about critical areas and sectors for action; supporting good policies 
and  reforms  by  DMCs;  and  contributing  to  global  development  discussions  by  offering 
perspectives from Asia and the Pacific. Through its contribution to and participation in the global 
review via knowledge products and events, ADB contributes to better awareness of how AfT can 
play an effective role in helping DMCs maximize the benefits of trade liberalization in an equitable 
manner, and leverage trade for inclusive and sustainable growth. 
 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
 
7.  ADB has been an active partner of and contributor to the WTO-led AfT Global Review 
since its inception in 2005. The TA cluster approach is most appropriate, given the 2-year cycle 
of the AfT Global Review. The TA cluster will enable ADB to continue its commitment to the WTO-
led AfT Global Review without potential interruption, and each cluster can focus on the theme that 
is aligned with the overall theme of the biennial AfT Global Review. The 2-year cycle also allows 
for in-depth analysis and rigorous peer review in the production of the biennial Aid for Trade in 
Asia and the Pacific report. Under the TA cluster, ADB will support the preparation of the next 
three Aid for Trade in Asia and the Pacific reports. 
 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
8.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impacts: (i) opportunities for further trade 
growth in Asia and the Pacific maximized and (ii) DMCs’ integration into the global economy 
                                                
5  Global trade volume growth accelerated to 4.7% in 2017 from 1.8% in 2016—surpassing global economic growth for 
the first time since 2012. Asia contributed about 35% of global volume growth. The region’s trade volume growth 
reached 7.1% in 2017, the highest since 2011, and largely supported the region’s gross domestic product growth. 
6  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
7  ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting Connectivity,

3 
heightened through increased trade openness. The TA cluster will have the following outcome: 
DMCs’ understanding of relevant trade opportunities, bottlenecks, and issues improved.8 
 
9.  Output 1: Aid for Trade in Asia and the Pacific reports published and disseminated. 
To provide a solid empirical and analytical foundation for the content of Aid for Trade in Asia and 
the Pacific reports (one report per subproject), the TA cluster will commission background 
research papers to supplement research of the Regional Cooperation and Integration Division 
(ERCI) on the selected theme topics. The theme of the seventh AfT Global Review in 2019 is 
Supporting Economic Diversification and Empowerment for Inclusive, Sustainable Development 
through Aid for Trade. The report will examine how international trade can promote inclusive 
growth and empowerment by (i) actively pursuing the participation of women and the growing 
youth population in trade-related activities; (ii) facilitating the integration of micro, small, and 
medium-sized enterprises into regional value chains and global trade; and (iii) promoting inclusive 
industrial development by broadening trade for the services sector and rural economy. Related 
areas of discussion include the role of digital connectivity, technology, and innovation to widen 
opportunities, improve access to finance, and foster skills development. A section of the report 
will be devoted to the challenges faced and progress made by the Pacific island economies, 
compared with other geographically challenged regions. Subsequently, the focus of the 2021 and 
2023 reports will be based on the themes of the eighth and ninth AfT Global Reviews respectively, 
within the overarching consideration of how best to leverage trade for inclusive and sustainable 
growth. 
 
10.  Output 2: Knowledge sharing events organized. The international launch of the Aid for 
Trade in Asia and the Pacific report during the AfT Global Review will be followed by knowledge 
sharing events cohosted by ADB development partners in Asia and the Pacific. Outreach will 
include analytical discussions of the issues in partnership with academic institutions, think tanks, 
and development partners. Distinguished economists and trade experts in the region will be 
invited to discuss the analytical rigor of the research work. Policy makers and private sector 
representatives will also be invited to the knowledge sharing events to generate discussions on 
the wider policy relevance. The publications will be widely disseminated in collaboration with 
ADB’s Department of Communications and participating resident missions, as well as with 
subregional programs.  
 
11.  Output  3:  Background  papers  published.  The  background  papers  will  also  be 
considered for publication as policy briefs and working papers to provide researchers with more 
extensive analyses related to the themes of the reports. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $750,000 ($250,000 for each TA subproject), of which 
(i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 
6) and (ii) $250,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia through the 
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and administered by ADB. Detailed cost estimates and 
financing arrangements will be presented in each TA subproject proposal submitted for approval.

consultants and resource persons; procure goods; organize workshops and conferences; consult

15.  Consulting services. Individual consultants will be recruited as needed for the duration 
of the TA cluster to provide about 28 person-months of international consulting inputs, including 
resource persons for conferences and other knowledge sharing events; and 138 person-months 
of national consulting inputs. The consultants will be engaged following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.10 Hiring a team of individual consultants will provide more benefits for 
ADB than engaging a firm because of the following reasons: (i) faster mobilization of consultants, 
(ii) greater control by the implementing agency in selecting and managing consultants, and (iii) 
greater flexibility in engaging experts specializing in a broad spectrum of AfT-related topics. 
 
16.  International consultants will be commissioned to prepare background research papers 
for selected topics in the Aid for Trade in Asia and the Pacific reports and to edit TA-related 
publications and written outputs. National consultants will include research and economic analysts 
who will assist ADB in the delivery of the TA cluster’s core outputs and in the preparation of the 
TA cluster’s publications and seminars. Other national consultants, including typesetters, graphic 
designers, and proofreaders, will be engaged for the publication of AfT and other reports and 
papers. Resource persons, who are internationally distinguished experts and could include ADB 
staff, will be engaged to present or facilitate discussions at seminars and other events. 
 
17.  A team of ERCI staff comprising two international staff members (one acting as the project 
leader and the leader of the team of consultants), one national officer, one operations coordinator, 
and one operations assistant will oversee and manage the implementation of the TA cluster. 
 
18.  ADB’s procurement. Purchases of information and communication technology-related 
equipment and/or supplies and econometric or statistical programs and/or software will follow the 
ADB  Procurement  Policy  and  the  Procurement  Regulations  for  ADB  Borrowers  (2017,  as 
amended from time to time), in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and 
Technology and Office of Administrative Services, where applicable.11 After the TA cluster is 
completed,  any  procured  equipment  will  be  disposed  following  the  Project  Administration 
Instructions on Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance.12Disbursements under this 
 
TA cluster will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). 
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $250,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia and 
(ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for Aid 
for Trade for Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
Subproject 1  Aid for Trade for Inclusive Growth, 2019–2020 
Indicative outputs and  Output 1: Aid for Trade in Asia and the Pacific 2019 report published and 
activities  disseminated 
Subproject 1 of the TA cluster will cover the publication of the Aid for Trade in 
Asia and the Pacific 2019 report, guided by the seventh AfT Global Review 
theme in 2019: Supporting Economic Diversification and Empowerment for 
Inclusive, Sustainable Development through Aid for Trade. The report will 
examine how international trade can promote inclusive growth and 
empowerment by actively pursuing the participation of women and the growing 
youth population in trade-related activities; facilitating MSMEs’ integration into 
regional value chains and global trade; and promoting inclusive industrial 
development by broadening trade for the services sector and rural economy. 
Toward these ends, the report will focus on how to address supply-side 
capacity, trade-related infrastructure, and financial constraints for MSMEs and 
women-led enterprises; and policies and measures that foster a dynamic, 
tradable service sector and enhance the productivity of the agriculture sector. 
Related areas of discussion include the role of digital connectivity, technology, 
and innovation to widen opportunities, improve access to finance, and foster 
skills development. A section of the report will be devoted to the challenges 
faced and progress made by the Pacific island economies, as compared with 
other geographically challenged regions of the world. 
 
Output 2: Knowledge sharing events organized 
The conferences and workshops will focus on the report’s theme. 
Distinguished economists and trade experts in the region will be invited to 
discuss the analytical rigor of the theme chapter, aligned with the theme of the 
AfT Global Review. Policy makers and private sector representatives will also 
be invited to the knowledge sharing events to generate discussions on the 
wider policy relevance of the research work. The publication will be widely 
disseminated in collaboration with ADB’s Department of Communications and 
participating resident missions. The international launch during the AfT Global 
Review will be followed by knowledge sharing events cohosted by ADB 
development partners in Asia and the Pacific. Outreach will include analytical 
discussions of the issues in partnership with academic institutions, think tanks, 
and development partners. 
 
Output 3: Background papers published 
The background papers will also be considered for publication as policy briefs 
and working papers to provide researchers with more extensive analyses 
related to the theme of the report.
